item.title: Israel Agrees to Extend Cease-Fire for 24 Hours
item.description: Hamas has not agreed to the humanitarian lull, but some Palestinian media reports said it was likely to do so.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: U.N. Warns of a Food Shortage 3 Years After Somalia’s Famine
item.description: The United Nations said that aid groups were unable to feed the more than 350,000 people in need in the capital, warning of “alarming malnutrition rates.”
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Israel Extends Cease-Fire in Gaza, a U.N. Request Rejected by Hamas
item.description: Hamas rejected the extension of the humanitarian lull for 24 hours, and Israel said it would continue to destroy tunnels from Gaza into its territory.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, left, spoke with France's foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, in Paris on Saturday.

item.title: In Search for Killer, DNA Sweep Exposes Intimate Family Secrets in Italy
item.description: The search for the killer in a sensational murder case revealed personal details about a suspect and set off a debate about the risks of privacy violations in DNA searches.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The cemetery in Italy, where Yara Gambirasio, 13, is buried. She was found dead in 2010 and in the search for her killer, the police gathered genetic samples from nearly 22,000 people.

item.title: Pause in the Fighting Gives Civilians on Both Sides a Moment to Take Stock
item.description: Saturday’s cease-fire provided the first daylong relief from violence for civilians since the start of the 19-day war between Israel and Palestinian militants.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli civilians and soldiers used a bathroom as a bomb shelter during a rocket attack near the border with Gaza on Saturday.

item.title: South Korea’s Epic Tragedy: In Ferry Deaths, a South Korean Tycoon’s Downfall
item.description: The sinking of the ferry Sewol killed 304 passengers and exposed a web of questionable business practices by Yoo Byung-eun, whose body was discovered last week near a villa where he had hidden.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN, MARTIN FACKLER, ALISON LEIGH COWAN and SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers and members of the news media at the scene where the body of Yoo Byung-eun was discovered last week in southern South Korea.

item.title: With Taliban’s Revival, Dread Returns to Swat
item.description: Militant violence — and the violence of the army’s response — is rising again in the verdant valley in Pakistan where five years ago soldiers supposedly banished the extremist element.
item.dc:creator: By ZIA ur-REHMAN and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: These child refugees seek to escape the fighting between the military and Islamist militants, but the violence is spreading.

item.title: Taliban Making Military Gains in Afghanistan
item.description: The insurgents’ increasing domination of key strategic areas has cast doubts on the government’s stability after the United States completes its withdrawal of combat troops.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan police recruits trained in Kabul on Tuesday. Security forces have been under increasing fire in areas around the capital.

item.title: Effort to Secure Malaysia Airline Crash Site Falters in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Fighting in eastern Ukraine on Saturday prevented Dutch military police officers from securing the site of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, while Russian news media stoked conspiracy theories of a secret Dutch military mission.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian State Emergency Service searched for bodies on Saturday near the village of Hrabove. The remains of most Malaysia Airlines victims have been recovered.

item.title: News Analysis: Why the U.N. Can’t Solve the World’s Problems
item.description: The trouble is not that the major powers don’t care. It is that they care too much.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Stan Honda/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Security Council members often use their veto power in high-stakes conflicts.

item.title: Bound by Bridge, 2 Baghdad Enclaves Drift Far Apart
item.description: Sunni Adhamiya and the Shiite Kadhimiya, linked by the Al Imams Bridge and once inextricably joined in the imagination of Baghdad residents, are drifting further and further apart.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: 2nd Air Algérie Black Box Is Found in Mali
item.description: United Nations specialists located a data recorder that may help determine what caused the jet to go down, killing all 118 people aboard.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Amid Outcry Abroad, a Wealth of Backing in Israel for Netanyahu
item.description: Facing growing international outcry over the ground assault in Gaza, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has found support from Israel’s politicians and people.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has so far not agreed to a broader cease-fire plan.

item.title: Facing Escalating Violence, U.S. Evacuates Staff From Its Embassy in Libya
item.description: Weeks of fighting between militias for control of Tripoli’s airport has edged toward the embassy in recent weeks, leading the State Department to close it and issue a travel warning.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Smoke rose after heavy fighting near the airport in Tripoli on Friday.

item.title: Pentagon Plan Would Help Ukraine Target Rebel Missiles
item.description: A proposal would let the Obama administration give precise locations of surface-to-air missiles controlled by Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine so the Ukrainian government could target them.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A Russian rocket system, similar to the one thought to have downed a civilian jet, at a 2011 show.

item.title: U.S. Could Help Ukraine Target Rebels’ Missiles
item.description: A proposal would let the Obama administration give precise locations of surface-to-air missiles controlled by Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine so the Ukrainian government could target them.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A Russian rocket system, similar to the one thought to have downed a civilian jet, at a 2011 show.

item.title: Gunmen Seize, Then Free, a Leading Iraqi Politician
item.description: It was not clear whether Riyadh al-Adhadh, who heads the Baghdad Provincial Council, was arrested by security forces or was abducted.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ex-Chief of C.I.A. Shapes Response to Detention Report
item.description: George J. Tenet, the former C.I.A. director, has been quietly engineering a counterattack against a Senate panel’s finding that officials misled Congress about an interrogation program.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:description: A military base in Stare Kiejkuty, Poland, which was a suspected location for the C.I.A.’s detentions and interrogations.

item.title: World Briefing: Afghanistan: Taliban Kill at Least 14 Bus Passengers
item.description: Taliban insurgents intercepted two minibuses traveling through central Afghanistan and killed at least 14 passengers, including women and a child, officials said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Russia Steps Up Help for Rebels in Ukraine War
item.description: Russia has accelerated its intervention, moving more of its own troops to its border with Ukraine, American and Ukrainian officials said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops in Semenovka, a village in the Donetsk region, on Friday. The United States said Russia had deployed high-powered Tornado rocket launchers.

item.title: World Briefing: Kyrgyzstan: Ex-Leader Convicted Over Crackdown
item.description: A former president of Kyrgyzstan was convicted and sentenced in absentia to life in prison on Friday for his role in violently breaking up an opposition rally, resulting in 77 deaths.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Sri Lankan Asylum Seekers to Be Moved Onshore
item.description: Sri Lankan asylum seekers who have been on an Australian customs vessel for weeks will be taken to Australia’s mainland for a temporary stay and may be sent to India, Australia’s government said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Drunken Driver Kills American Peace Activist
item.description: A 61-year-old American man who was cycling in Russia carrying “messages of peace” was killed by a Russian drunken driver in a hit-and-run accident, the news agency Itar-Tass reported the local police as saying on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Government Confirms a Death From Ebola
item.description: West Africa’s current Ebola outbreak has spread to a fourth country, as Nigeria on Friday confirmed a death caused by the disease.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: E.U. Seeks Quick Approval for Russian Sanctions
item.description: The European Union has accelerated efforts to enact tougher economic sanctions against Russia, despite the difficulty of creating a resolution that will not hurt the rest of Europe’s economy.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
